question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a variety of technical terms that I didn't know anything about before (pilasters, entablatures, etc.) 
I learned the professional relationships between Renaissance architects (ex. being able to compare/contrast Vasari to Michelangelo to Bramante)
I learned how to balance a modern aesthetic with the rules of antiquity architecture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of architectural terms, construction methods, and how architecture is related to politics and economics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical thinking skills and beautiful insights on renaissance architecture. I also developed better writing skills that helped me get to the point of what I was saying faster.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Application of architectural elements to new buildings presented in later classes --- using information from prior discussions to understand the architectural strategies presented in later discussions.Understanding lifestyles of different time periods and putting ourselves into the shoes of those people, walking through the buildings, to understand why they were built in a specific manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Learned a lot about specific Renaissance history, not only architectural but also general history, which was incredibly interesting as the background of the Renaissance is important to understand the architecture that came out of it. 
I learned how to think extra-critically about architecture, and realize how interconnected everyone involved in architectural history is. I also learned many things about the process of creating books and how printing worked. This may seem like a weird thing to take from this class, but understanding how books were made really helps with analyzing the old architectural books that we got ahold of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to identify, categorize, examine, and otherwise engage with the architecture and history of Renaissance buildings. Learning about their function, how they came to be, who was responsible for them, where they are located, what influenced their design and in turn what designs they themselves influenced, how they were effected by historical events - all of these things were learned through this course, and it was very very enjoyable to learn!! Incredibly thorough and well-rounded!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to take effective notes, as these types of classes are out of my comfort zone and i'm not used to a heavy lecture class. I learned a lot about the connected between architecture and history and how certain time periods, like the renissance, reflect the style of architecture that is used in the buildings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Course content follow from background introduction to Renaissance to a chronological look into the works, techniques, and context of masters throughout the 15th and 16th century. I like how each work builds on another previous work or technique, which allows students to get a holistic sense of what defines Renaissance architecture and what makes it unique.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was a very intimate class setting... only nine students. We all sit in a U-shape facing the smartboard and she speaks directly to us so that we can ask questions at any point.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I did appreciate that the slides that the professor lectured from didn't have all of the words that she was saying. This is because it is much more intriguing to hear from her rather than have her just read off a slide, which is something i can do. It makes the class more engaging and forces you to pay attention. It was also very easy to raise your hand and ask questions- most professors would ignore you if you had your hand up until they decided they were done, but in this class I could raise my hand and get my question answered immediately, which was very engaging. Additionally, one of my favorite parts was going to the library and reading books from close to the Renaissance period. It's great because it allowed me to be personally connected with the content of the course; having a physical grasp of history is absolutely fascinating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class, while situated as a lecture, really felt like more of a discussion sometimes, and I loved everything about it. Professor Galletti really talked TO the class rather than AT the class, which made the material a lot easier to engage with, and facilitated connections and engagement for the course material. The assigned readings were always elaborated upon and tied directly into the day's lesson, which really helped me understand them better. The trips to the library to see first-hand the materials that we were discussing in the class, such as Alberti's 1st edition publications and such, were very cool and made it much easier to remember / build upon.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: A lot of the learning in this course was through lectures and related readings. These lectures were very detailed and specific but helped with learning a lot about Renaissance architecture and Italy and the important architects in that time period. Because of the detailed lectures, I was able to have a deep understanding on the topic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It was awesome. If you are interested in art history, architecture, or life during the Renaissance, it is certainly a class you should take. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The biggest thing I learned was how to learn the humanities. I've really only studied for STEM + history classes before this class so I had to figure out a different method to study.
2. Appreciation for the culture around me. Now, I notice Italian a lot more around me in everyday life when I previously wasn't aware of how intertwined it was in my day-to-day life.
3. Of course I also learned Italian. The class taught me the fundamentals and basics of Italian to the points where I could possibly sustain a conversation in Italian, when I wasn't able to in Latin, Spanish, German, or any of my other pass attempts to learn a language.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was an amazing language class.  The materials were blended nicely between in-person conversation and practice speaking/listening, with didactics and online/textbook learning, and interpersonal vidoes.  I really liked the talkabroad and that, in general, assignments and learning were based around speaking and listening to Italian.  So, I learned a surprising amount of vocabulary, grammar, and proficiency speaking and understanding italian.  I was a bit ambivalent whether I could or would continue past this semester.  But, after seeing how much I have learned and how excellent this course was in terms of materials and quality of instruction, I certainly am continuing my learning of italian language and culture at Duke.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was a wonderful class.  The materials and syllabus were very well-laid out and thoughtful.  Laura in particular does an amazing job of keeping the class lively and interesting.  Clearly the lessons were always very thoughtfully prepared, as were the supplemental learning materials and assignments.  Expectations were always very clear.  I think honestly what made the class so helpful and fun was Laura's personality and commitment.  She is always positive and engaging while maintaining control of the class and expectations.  She was kind in meeting any time to practice (office hours or otherwise) and she was kind and supportive in instances where my schedule in particular was at odds with the syllabus and class. That made such a difference in my enjoyment and motivation to continue.  In terms of the logistics and format, honestly I thought it was all good.  I liked the asynchronous activities and the talkabroad.  The sentieri homework was very important to ensure I engaged and studied each night as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love how the course gives you so many opportunities to practice Italian, via online assignments, mini projects, mini quizzes, and writing assignments. I especially appreciate how every assignment counts for a small portion of your grade - if you do poorly on one assignment, it is not the be-all and end-all.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor evaluated us often. Grammar and vocabulary were evaluated on quizzes and short in class essays, and speaking was evaluated through short conversations with a classmate or Talkabroad conversations with a native speaker. I think frequent evaluation of our progress was the most effective component of the course because it forces you to practice daily and study. It also ensures that you don’t fall behind, and holds you accountable for getting better with the language. Also, the assessments were all very fair. With a reasonably small amount of outside work, I was able to get 100 on most.

response_text: In this course, I made real progress with my Italian. My grammar improved a lot, and I feel much more confident speaking and understanding everyday Italian. One of the biggest changes was that I can now hold a basic conversation with a native speaker, which I couldn't do before. I also learned not to be afraid of making mistakes—our professor always made sure the classroom felt like a safe space where it was okay to try, mess up, and learn from it. Finally, I started thinking differently about language learning overall. It became more about communication and less about perfection, which made a big difference in my confidence.

response_text: The learning environment was great, mainly thanks to our professor, Pierpaolo Spagnolo. He was one of the most patient and understanding instructors I’ve ever had. He explained things clearly, used real-life examples, and made the class fun with his sense of humor. As a student-athlete, I really appreciated how flexible and supportive he was—he never had an issue if I had to miss a class for a tournament, and he would even stay after class to let me make up quizzes. The way he encouraged participation made a big difference too. People weren’t scared to speak, even when they made mistakes. I will for sure try to take another course with him. Great guy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so many things from grammatic rules to the italian culture. I love this class very much, but three things that stuck with me were the use of "credo che" and "penso che". Another thing that is leaving with me after this semester ends is the variety of food recipes. For example, how to prepare tiramisu or cannoli. Not only that but how to make pasta from scratch from the Tavola Italian event. Lastly, what I loved most learning in this class was the immigration issues in Italy. For example, I was able to understand it better through the analysis of the show Zero. But, then in our individual/group projects and research, I was able to understand how Ghali (a rapper) who is a rapper and second generation living in Italy survives the stereotypes and rising problems with the laws. I felt freedom throughout the whole course because every group project within the unit was chosen by us (like the person we wanted to do research on or theme). Moreover, I learned about what it is like working with other students while speaking italian. This was helpful practice outside of class because not only was it homework to complete, but it pushed us to stay constant of our use of italian language. I really enjoyed getting together whether it was in partners or groups to work outside of class. I enjoyed presenting and working on presentation and oral skills in the italian language. It gave me a sense of confidence.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great class to continue practicing Italian. It is an accelerated course so expect homework every night but I think that Laura managed to make the work interesting and entertaining. For example, for one homework assignment we had to go get gelato. There were different activities that helped keep me engaged. I also think that it's helpful to ask a lot of questions. The professor is very willing to answer and help you understand but don't wait until the big projects or a quiz to try and learn something. I would definitely recommend this and I would say that Laura does a great job of giving a general review in the beginning of the course since she knows that we all come from different levels of Italian. I hadn't taken an Italian course in a year and I felt that I caught up fairly quickly.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course and the Duke In Bologna program will not be the easiest study abroad that you can do in Italy. I argue that you will improve your Italian skills more than in many other courses. I will say that it is a lot of work 4 times a week a 3-hour class and 2 times a week a 2-hour class. Additionally, outside of class, you are expected to attend multiple required museum visits and exhibits. The grading of the classes is fair and you should get an A as long as you put in a decent amount of work. You also have a 3-day weekend where you can go travel with the group or on your own. I would recommend taking this course to fulfill the language requirement, but also if you are really interested in traveling. If you are usually the type of person that likes to have a couple of hours of relaxation time on the weekend, I would not recommend the course since we always have something to do which can be good and bad at times.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Taking this class in Bologna was a life-changing opportunity, definitely take it if at all possible.

response_text: It is highly rigorous but the topics are relevant to adjusting to life while living abroad.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned many things about the process of creating books and how printing worked. This may seem like a weird thing to take from this class, but understanding how books were made really helps with analyzing the old architectural books that we got ahold of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

It was also very easy to raise your hand and ask questions- most professors would ignore you if you had your hand up until they decided they were done, but in this class I could raise my hand and get my question answered immediately, which was very engaging. Additionally, one of my favorite parts was going to the library and reading books from close to the Renaissance period. It's great because it allowed me to be personally connected with the content of the course; having a physical grasp of history is absolutely fascinating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The assigned readings were always elaborated upon and tied directly into the day's lesson, which really helped me understand them better. The trips to the library to see first-hand the materials that we were discussing in the class, such as Alberti's 1st edition publications and such, were very cool and made it much easier to remember / build upon.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We read the entirety of The Divine Comedy, as well as the Vita Nuova and some supplements, so I learned quite a bit about Dante himself, as well as the political, theological, and philosophical environment in which he was situated compared to his own ideology. I learned how to analyze different translations of the text side-by-side, how to critique commentaries, and how to find relevant parallels between the different cantica. I also learned how to express all of this in writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to engage with an arduous piece of literature from seven centuries ago, analyzing many political, theological and ethical themes that are relevant for today's world. I learned to read intently and read with purpose, clarifying the poem as I went through and engaging in critical discussions with my peers. Ultimately, my essays allowed me to exercise my knowledge on the poem and deepened my understanding every single time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Eisner is one of my favorite professors at Duke. He is one of the most knowledgeable Dantean scholars out there, and his enthusiasm about Dante is infectious. His slides are so well-curated and he has so many random fun facts, e.g. about Virgil's pesto recipe on the US dollar bill. I thought the reading assignments were well-paced for the most part. The midterm was mostly fair passage identification and some factual information (expecting the final to be similarly fair). The papers were actually quite fun to write because we could choose to write about any translations, parallels, and commentaries we thought were most intriguing, i.e. there was a lot of free rein. The group activities, like the in-class art project, were great. I enjoyed the guest lecturer as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Martin Eisner elevated my learning experience of Dante's Divine Comedy through his energetic personality and thought-provoking insights into a rather esoteric poem. He elucidated a lot of thoughts I had coming in when I briefly read about 12 cantos. He forced us to grapple with many dimensions of Dante's poem and challenged my many preconceived notions on love, free will, the existence of a soul, and the role of mentorship within life. I would love to keep the whole presence of Professor Eisner within the course as I cannot imagine a more suitable professor to guide us through the dark wood that is the Spring semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class!! Prof Eisner is an amazing professor with so much Dantean knowledge to offer, as well as fun facts that you definitely did not know. It's a lot of reading, but it is worth it. Exams are not too bad if you actually read the poem.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dante's Divine Comedy is not just a story about a pilgrim who struggles to reach a heavenly paradise with Virgil as his guide, but rather leverages his writing to put the reader in an oasis chock-full of his own intimate thoughts regarding love, free will, the divinity of God. He is not afraid to step outside orthodox boundaries to go after people he doesn't like. Dante Alighieri freely and frequently brandishes his ire against 14th century ecclesial figures and put them through heart-wrenching methods of suffering. This coupled with an acute sense of self-awareness makes it hard to hate an exiled 14th century Italian man's charisma.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend this course! It is a great opportunity to improve analytical skills, critical thinking and to know more about European history as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. Various Sociolinguistic Concepts and Theories
2. Real-life Examples and Cases of Sociolinguistic Hierarchies/Discrimination
3. How to Analyze the Speech or Linguistic Characteristics of Different Groups

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: reading difficult texts, understanding discrimination in linguistics, in class discussion, organizing thoughts, syntehsis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The central concepts of how language and the use of language in certain communities can influence the way you perceive the world around you and how others may perceive yourself.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The knowledge I took away from this course mainly was how connected identity is to language. Not only identity I also learned how the language we use represents parts of cultural background along with language ideologies that introduce social hierarchies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: After taking this course, I have learned that language plays a salient role in identity formation. Before taking this course, I was unaware of the numerous language ideologies in society. Still, this course showed me that these ideologies alter how we interact with others in society. Despite language being a form of communication, there are so many ways people can interact with one another that do not involve a "formal" language. This course has also introduced me to many native languages and language varieties that exist today that I was not aware of previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was challenged to think about my identity and the identity of others in relation to language in deep and interesting ways. We explored diverse populations of many ethnicities, races, social standings and countries to investigate how our language pervades the concept of who we are and how we are perceived.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply semiotics (sign, symbol, index) to different situations and topics. I learned terms like community of practice, style shifting, and pragmatics, among others, that have helped me to give concrete, concise terminology to phenomena I couldn't otherwise describe. I learned about the difference between covert and overt prestige as it relates to communities of practice and language varieties.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained knowledge about the class topic (Language & Identity & Constructing Social Hierarchies), I learnt methods of sociolinguistics, and developed ways of thinking about the nature of language.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: I feel as though Dr.Fellin created a safe and judgement free space for learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings/homework assignments, having discussions with classmates, and presenting readings to the class helped facilitate my learning because they allowed me to stay engaged with the content of the course while hearing about of the insights that my classmates had as well. I will also say that the readings for this course were very interesting and they taught me so much about language's role in society.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The texts that we were asked to read for homework covered a breadth of populations from indigenous identities to Asian American identities. There was diversity in the authors themselves which was appreciated as I felt Prof L made an effort to include literature that was not biased to WEIRD populations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the readings a lot, I don't think I would cut any of them. Luciana was very helpful and understanding of personal problems, so I didn't feel that my learning was impeded.

response_text: Professor is an absolute sweetheart! She managed to foster an environment in the classroom that provided me with a safe place where I felt comfortable making potential mistakes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the conversations! the readings! the assignments! circling back to themes we had already discussed and introducing new learnings or understandings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions we had in the class were very helpful in learning from anecdotes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The amount of interactive work we did with peers made the class stimulating

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings, the homework assignments, the class presentations, and the papers/final assignments made the course intellectually stimulating because they encouraged students to stay engaged and to think outside of the box.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated Prof L's flexibility with topics, assignment and readings. Prof was very responsive to class interest and would engineer the class as time went on to react to the interests that had arisen in the class and also the wider context of life (i.e the election). This made the class engaging, relevant and interesting. Prof L was very adept at responding to varying interests and abilities of the class ranging from individuals who were very interested in the study of linguistics to those who were taking a linguistics class for the first time. There was a constant revision of key terms and concepts so no one was left behind.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The way in which we explored different sociolinguistic concepts through media and research literature was stimulating. It kept me thinking about the topics we addressed and their applications in other situations I'm familiar with.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The material itself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: SO INTERESTING! Will open your eyes to linguistics everywhere. Literally shifts the way you think about language!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was extremely insightful and I am much more aware of how I use language after taking this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is both a great entrance and continuation for anyone if you may be studying linguistics for the first time or if this is your 5th linguistics class. You can get out of the class exactly what you put into it and can spark the exploration of interesting topics that can be applied to your experience with language at Duke and for the rest of your life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this is one of the courses at Duke with a perfect balance of elements that lends itself well to learning; I would highly recommend it.

response_text: Take it! It is a lot of fun! Interesting, but not so difficult!
